title: How to Make Camarones a La Diabla

text: Peel and season the shrimp with salt and pepper as desired. Tails can be completely torn off or you can leave them on if you'd like. Leave the shrimp in the mixing bowl in the fridge, for later. Remove the seeds and stems from the chiles guajillo and the chiles de arbol. The easiest way to remove seeds is to split the pepper down the center and carve them out with a spoon or knife. Set your burner to medium with a dry skillet. Toast both the dry chile guajillo and chile de arbol for 5 to 6 minutes. Boil water and add after 5 minutes of toasting. Cover the skillet with a lid and let it simmer for 15-18 min, or until the chiles are soft. Slice and dice tomatoes, onions, and fresh garlic. Then transfer them to a blender for the next step. Since you are blending all the ingredients together, the pieces do not have to be perfect. Use a slotted spoon transfer the soft chiles into the blender. Add the salt. Puree for about 3 minutes until the sauce is all a uniform color. Store the chile sauce in dish and cover with a paper towel for now. Heat the olive oil in a clean skillet on medium heat. Add the seasoned shrimp. Lay the shrimp flat on one side so that you can cook the shrimp for 1 minute on each side. Flip each shrimp individually to ensure that all shrimp are cooked thoroughly. Add the sauce puree to the pan with the shrimp. Stir very gently for 3-5 minutes. If a thicker consistency is desired, stir for 10-15 minutes. Remove the pan from heat. Serve the Camarones a La Diabla with rice and garnish with cucumber.
